From: tom.watson@tradingco.com
To: adam.rivera@shipbroker.com
Subject: CPO Shipment Inquiry - Medan to Manila
Timestamp: 2023-07-01 09:15
Body: Hey Mr. Rivera,

Quick question: any laycan slots left in the first week of July for 9,500MT of crude palm oil from Medan to Manila? Also, what daily demurrage rate are you proposing?

Best,
Tom

---
From: adam.rivera@shipbroker.com
To: tom.watson@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: CPO Shipment Inquiry - Medan to Manila
Timestamp: 2023-07-01 11:30
Body: Great to connect Tom,

I am running a shipping business focused on existing and emerging markets. We have partners across major ports in Asia, South America, Middle East, and Africa.

Regarding your palm oil inquiry, could you provide more details about your requirements? What's your preferred loading window and any specific vessel requirements?

Look forward to your response.

Best regards,
Adam Rivera

---
From: tom.watson@tradingco.com
To: adam.rivera@shipbroker.com
Subject: Re: CPO Shipment Inquiry - Medan to Manila
Timestamp: 2023-07-01 14:45
Body: Adam,

What's the story behind the price and production numbers in that email? Can you forward me any articles or reports on palm oil market conditions?

Regards,
Tom

---
From: adam.rivera@shipbroker.com
To: tom.watson@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: CPO Shipment Inquiry - Medan to Manila
Timestamp: 2023-07-02 08:20
Body: Tom,

Apologies for my delayed response. I've been quite busy with other commitments. I've reviewed the cargo details and discussed with our partners. While I can't disclose specific buyer/seller information, I can confirm the vessel availability and rates for your required loading window.

Shall we proceed with discussing the specific terms?

Best regards,
Adam

From: chris.smith@trader.com
To: jane.wilson@shipping.com
Subject: Corn Oil Shipment Inquiry - Galveston to Qingdao
Timestamp: 2024-05-01 09:30
Body: Hello,

Can your vessel load 4,000MT of corn oil from Galveston to Qingdao by the end of May? We are looking for an L/C T/C with an expiry of 15 days.

Best,
Chris

---
From: jane.wilson@shipping.com
To: chris.smith@trader.com
Subject: Re: Corn Oil Shipment Inquiry - Galveston to Qingdao
Timestamp: 2024-05-16 18:45
Body: Hi,

This vessel arrived at Qingdao at the end of the day on 16 May. It is ready for discharge and we are unable to arrange unloading before 19 May. We would appreciate if you could send an amended voyage estimate to our agent so we can approve it as soon as possible.

Looking forward to hearing from you.

Best,
Jane

---
From: chris.smith@trader.com
To: jane.wilson@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Corn Oil Shipment Inquiry - Galveston to Qingdao
Timestamp: 2024-05-17 10:15
Body: Hi Jane,

Could you let me know your appointed agent in Qingdao please? We can contact them directly. Also, your intention of discharging on 19 May is not acceptable to us. A vessel lies idle for 10 days at Qingdao is unacceptable for us. If you can't start discharging before 18 May, we are looking for a counter-offer.

Thank you.

Best,
Chris

---
From: jane.wilson@shipping.com
To: chris.smith@trader.com
Subject: Re: Corn Oil Shipment Inquiry - Galveston to Qingdao
Timestamp: 2024-05-17 14:30
Body: Dear Chris,

We have appointed JPT as our agent in Qingdao. This is their contact information:

JPT International Co. Ltd.
Address: Block A, Room 802, No.10 DongHaiNan Road, Qingdao, 266061, P.R.China
Phone: 86-532-80780378/80780379
Fax: 86-532-80780380

Best regards,
Jane

---
From: jane.wilson@shipping.com
To: chris.smith@trader.com
Subject: Re: Corn Oil Shipment Inquiry - Galveston to Qingdao
Timestamp: 2024-05-17 16:45
Body: Dear Chris,

We are concerned with the delay on loading by your charterer in Galveston. We suggest that your charterer completes loading before the vessel arrives in Qingdao. Otherwise, your charterer has to pay the vessel demurrage.

Our voyage estimate has already been prepared and is on its way to you. This is a copy of the voyage estimate for your reference.

Please also note that, according to your contract, the charterer is responsible for the costs of shifting between berths.

Best regards,
Jane

A booking reference number is a unique number that is given to a customer when they make a booking for a product or service. The number is used to identify the customer's booking and to keep track of it. The number may be given to the customer in a confirmation email or letter, or it may be printed on the customer's booking form. The booking reference number is typically used to look up the customer's booking when they call or email to ask a question or make a change to their booking.

Dear Ms. Annabelle,                    Hello. Thank you for your e-mail. I have several storage tanks and packing equipment available and I will be able to accept a 5,000MT shipment of waste plastic film starting July 28. As for the lead time, it will take me about four days to finish the tanking of the plastic film. I can do all the loading, stuffing and lashing and you will be responsible for the fixing and sealing of the hatch. Will the cargo be using hatch cover or will it be double-containerized? Please advise, so I can make the necessary arrangements for the storage. Will you be able to cover the last two shipments for $2,500? We could not accept this kind of condition because the terminal handling fees and port storage costs are already included in the quoted price. I think the best arrangement we could do is to have a rate adjustment

Email 1:
Dear Mr. Thomas,                    We’re looking to move   some dry bulk cargo from Apapa to Durban on short notice. Could you share your earliest loading window?                    Regards,                    Janelle
Email 2:
Dear Colleagues,      Our kind team is invited to London for IMO/SGS market hearing. Looking for your meeting schedule or collective guidance from DCS. What is your opinion for SGH support project?                            Regards,                    Ria

Answering both of these emails at the same time is often not possible. Even with the help of tools, like Changelog.io , can save time. 
Typically, you would need to spend some time each day, looking through the emails you’ve gotten, and only answer the ones you can actually answer, saving the others for later. 

A chat bot can also do that. With a Machine Learning and NLP model, the bot can answer the questions that it has answers to, or store them to answer later, and reply to your other colleagues later, with their questions still in place. 

If the first question above is related to

Email 1:
Mr. Silver,                    We’re looking for a 500 ton cargo of corn from Quebec to Tokyo. Could you provide a freight quote under CFR terms, and can your vessel sail before the 20th?                    Best regards,                    Gordon
Email 2:
Silver Shipping
Mr. Silver,
Thank you for your reply. We have already loaded on a vessel and made the transportation contract. However, the transportation company asks for the following documents: a set of bills of lading, a certificate of insurance and a set of commercial invoices. I would appreciate your advice.
Yours sincerely,
Tom

The problem of Cargo Document is tricky because it involves the dispute on whether the transportation company should be considered as the agent of the seller.

Business background:
The first email shows that the buyers have agreed on an acceptance to offer (letter of acceptance, cf. § 1384, Italian Code of Commercial law (Codice Commerciale)) and made a transportation contract for the 500 ton cargo of corn with a third party. As for the Seller, the second email shows that the Seller still thinks that the transportation company is his agent and the Buyers are not
Email 3:
Dear Gordon,
Silver Shipping, Inc. is currently arranging the shipping for you. It will be more convenient if you could tell us the name of the third party or the transportation company to deal with the shipping contract. We are looking forward to getting your email. Thank you very much.
Yours sincerely,
Michael Silver, President Silver Shipping, Inc.
</Email 3>

The main issue:
For the transaction to be a sale with CIF clause, at the moment of conclusion of the contract of sale, the Seller and the Buyers have to agree on the destination port and the Seller have to insure the goods for the Buyers. If the Buyers do not have a transportation contract, the Seller must comply with this CIF clause to fulfill the contract. Otherwise, the Seller should not promise the contract with the Buyers at all, which is the same as Article 6 § 1 (c) of the ICC
Email 4:
Gordon,
Mr. Silver would like to know where you have got the buyers of the corn. We have already got buyers but you asked for the freight and insurance costs. We do not understand why. As we agreed, you are responsible for the sale, insurance and transportation of the corn. We expect to see a written transportation contract from you within the next 3 days. Please forward to Mr. Silver a copy of the transportation contract.
Yours sincerely,
Bill
</Email 4>
The point is that the Seller has not decided what destination port the Buyers are going to choose yet. It seems that the Sellers have fulfilled all the CIF obligations in this case. Thus, it is unnecessary to involve any transportation company. If there is no such transportation company that the Seller and the Buyers both use, the contract of sale cannot be considered as a CIF contract. Therefore, the Sellers should not

Email 1:
Hi Kathy,                    Has the grounding of the Seablue had any impact on your crude fixing level for the short term?                    Thanks,                    Blayney
Email 2:
Hi Blayney,                    Not at all.                    Seablue is a crude vessel and almost all crude cargoes have been fixed by the other time-chartered tankers coming out of  Chinese yards.
As I mentioned previously, if Seablue did not come out in China, other tankers would come out of the dock and China would be fixed.                    These tankers would operate at a price level set by the most competitive time charter tanker which is the drydocked Seablue and therefore the price level at which China is fixed would not be different even if Seablue was out of the drydock.
LPG cargoes are different since we can not use LPG in the crude tankers and crude cargoes are not as easy to fix as LPG, since many producers are contracted and certain prices are set.
The next drydocked Seablue is in

Email 1:
Hello Ms. Scott,                    Can you look at the market rate for 2 x 50foot containers of crude oil from Balikpapan to Jakarta, 22nd to 23rd of the month?                    Regards,                    Emma
Email 2:
Hi,                    We bought 2 x 50foot containers of crude oil from Balikpapan to Jakarta for 700 USD.                    All the best,                    Emma

After investigating 82 oil container rates in Balikpapan from February to May 2016, Emma wrote email 1 to request advice on market rates for the 22nd to 23rd of the month. When the suggested rate was below market rate, she accepted the offer via email 2.

Solution:
The correct answer is a2, and the explanation is as follows:
The business communication has the characteristic of taking the buyer's interest into consideration. The buyer is assumed to be the focus in business communication.
Email 3:
Dear Ms. Scott,                   We would like to purchase some crude oil. We have a request for a load of cargo delivered to China on or around the 22nd to 23rd of this month. What is the market rate for this?                    Regards,                    Emma

Answer Options:
a1. Email 3 asked the oil supplier for the market rate of oil containers and the price, which shows great concern for the buyer's interest.
a2. The oil supplier provides a quotation below the market rate in email 4, showing concern for the buyer's interest.
a3. The oil supplier provided a quotation that was on par with the market rate in email 4, showing no concern for the buyer's interest.
a4. The oil supplier provided a quotation that was much higher than the market rate in email 4, showing great concern for the buyer's interest.
a5

output_text:
From: john.smith@chemicalimports.com
To: jonas.berg@freightbroker.com
Subject: Rate Request - Isopropanol Shipment Houston to Cartagena
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:15
Body: Dear Jonas,

Please provide a rate estimate for 4,800 MT of isopropanol from Houston to Cartagena. We'd like to get this to our factory for production as soon as possible. Do you do cargo insurance under DAP terms?

Regards,
John

---
From: john.smith@chemicalimports.com
To: jonas.berg@freightbroker.com
Subject: Re: Rate Request - Isopropanol Shipment Houston to Cartagena
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:45
Body: Dear Jonas,

To clarify on my previous email, the 4,800 MT of isopropanol will be packed in 3x20' containers and 2x40' containers with a total capacity of 96 TEUs.

Best regards,
John

---
From: jonas.berg@freightbroker.com
To: john.smith@chemicalimports.com
Subject: Re: Rate Request - Isopropanol Shipment Houston to Cartagena
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 11:30
Body: Dear John,

Thank you for your inquiry. I am sending you a quote for your review. We will require a 25% deposit to secure the space.

Once the space is secured, we will provide the details for your local bank to remit payment, as well as the full details of your cargo insurance and bill of lading requirements.

Our next step will be to have our operations department send you the cargo insurance declaration forms to initiate the insurance coverage process. Once the insurance has been set up, we will begin the shipment process and provide you with all necessary documentation.

Best regards,
Jonas

Hi James,                    I have a load of palm kernel oil coming from Port Klang to Male. I’d like to move 5,000MT of oil. I have an email below from a freight forwarder in Port Klang, could you help me out with an indicative freight?                    Cheers,                    Mona
Email 2:
Hi Mona,                    Thanks for the enquiry. So you are looking for a freight quote to move 5,000MT of palm kernel oil from Port Klang to Male?                    I’ll need more details about the cargo before I can give you a quote. Could you please let me know:
    the quality and cleanliness of the cargo,
    the minimum temperature the cargo must be kept at on board,
    if you need a refrigerated vessel, and
    what type of stowage is required.
                    I’ll need to know who will arrange for the stowage, loading, discharge and clearance as this will affect the charges.
                    Please email all these details to me as soon as you can. Once I have the information, I will be able to provide you with an indicative freight quote.                    Looking forward to hearing from you.                    Best regards,                    James

Email 1:
Hi John,                    Our Singapore client would like to transport 2,800MT of naphtha from Baltimore to Dahej, but we don’t have enough funds on hand for the margin fee. Could you spot us?                    Hope you can help.                    Kim
Email 2:
From: John G                 Sent: 23 February 2012 18:00                 To: Kim T                 Subject: Spot us?                 Not a chance! Hope you can spot my answer.                 John

Problem

A recent widespread email spam campaign targeted the energy and commodities trading industry with messages claiming that their customers wanted to use their services to buy crude oil and related products from reputable traders in the market. Some traders were approached in a very business-like manner, allegedly by major oil firms. The email subject line would indicate that the email was from a trusted business partner, such as a large energy firm or similar corporate client.

The email requests are easy to read but hard to understand. A foreign sounding person claiming to be an executive from a respectable company in a similar industry wants to “spot” some “margin fee” – what? An explanation for what these terms mean may have come attached
Email 3:
Dear John,                    Thank you for your reply.                    Our Singapore client is Singapore Energy, one of the leading trading and logistics companies in Asia Pacific. They represent a major Japanese refiner, Osaka Gas.                    It’s true that this is a complicated trading project and we have to pay a relatively high margin fee of USD 1,000.000.                    If you don’t mind, I can arrange to send you the contract and payment procedure, so that you can fully understand the situation.                    Have a good day.                    Kim

When a business receives a large unsolicited order they often feel obligated to make the sale. In this instance, we can probably deduce that our client is confused as to what the client actually wants and also may be uncomfortable with all the business jargon. In both situations, the client should take a step back and evaluate the order. First, the client should
Email 4:
Dear John,                    Thank you for your reply.                    I am really sorry to trouble you. My name is Alihac, Assistant to the CEO of Singapore Energy.                    I’d like to discuss with you about the details of the project.                    Please let me know when you are free.                    Best regards,                    Kim

As the requests are unsolicited and we have not received any communication with our buyer in the past, it would be a good idea to contact them directly to confirm their intent. We could ask the buyer for more information and maybe arrange to speak with the buyer directly. When speaking with the buyer, it would be important to ask them to provide more information about the deal. The buyer may have a reasonable explanation for their request. However, it is important to keep in mind that a reasonable explanation does not necessarily mean the request is legitimate.

Conclusion

This type of email scam

Email 1:
Hi Reza,                    I’d like to schedule 40,000MT of molasses from Santos to Jawahar Nagar. We’re open to spot charterers, but this cargo may require some creativity in terms of planning. Could you please let me know if you are open to this size charter?                    Thank you,                    Rosalind
Email 2:
Hi Rosalind                    Just sent you a revised LSA with the same details.                    Best regards                    Reza

Thanks, Reza

Below is Rosalind's reaction to Reza's invitation.
Email 3:
You are good, its working perfect :)

All the best,
Rosalind

So she already appreciated the role of Reza’s proposing concrete example as shown in the second email above.

For general reference, a LSA is a LOI (letter of intent) document.

Introduction

The use of “Email 1” as an example is taken from a popular LinkedIn post of Sam Nara on the subject of using a working example when making a proposal (source: Linkedin).

I have learned a lot from Sam’s post, and I think the post helps provide an excellent practical starting point. In this post, I will provide further explanations to highlight more subtle points not included in Sam’s original post, and also discuss how these points are implemented in our Lean Email.

Email 1 is a typical email. Its objective is to propose a working example to a recipient.

In practice, Rosalind
Email 4:
Thank you so much!
<...>
I do need your help here to review and submit the revised LSA to admin for approvals!

In this example, Rosalind first thanked Reza for sending her a revised LSA, then reminded Reza that she required his help to proceed with the transaction.

Based on this email, Reza needs to do two things to support Rosalind in closing this transaction:

• Review the LSA before submitting the LSA to Rosalind’s admin for approvals.
• Submit the LSA to Rosalind’s admin for approvals.

Reza can do these two tasks simply by using Lean Email by clicking the buttons as shown below. Clicking on the Review button will pop-up a Review/Submit page, which contains a Review tab, and a Submit tab.

Clicking on the Review tab, Reza can simply enter a quick review note, and

Email 1:
Dear Ms. Armitage,                    Want to discuss options for a scheduled bulk chartered from Singapore to Jakarta, loading 15,000 MT of rice.                    Thanks,                    Sally
Email 2:
Ms. Armitage                    Hi Sally,                In reference to your email, we may consider to organize a chartered out of Singapore with loading to be completed by around 20 to 22 Nov, with delivery ETA expected to be around 10 to 12 Dec. For your reference, I have attached the chartered info and telex release copy.                If you are interested, I will keep you posted when we have further update.                Regards,                Tony

</Email 2>

# Word Problem

### Solution 1

From the email the relevant facts are:

• The farmer wants to charter a ship to transport 15000 mt of rice to Jakarta.
• According to Ms. Armitage, the loading can be completed by around 20–22 November with delivery ETA around 10–12 December.

We know the ship will depart Singapore to Jakarta but
Email 3:
Hi Sally,                There will be another chartered starting from Singapore to Jakarta, departing on 18 Nov.                If you are interested, please advise latest by 15 Nov.                Regards,                Tony

</Email 3>

The sender mentions in Email 3 that the ship will leave Singapore to Jakarta on 18 November. That means there will be a time difference between 18 November and 20 November. So this information is not consistent with the information given in Email 2, which is the main source of information.

One reason for inconsistency could be the mistake in Email 2, when Ms. Armitage wrote 22 November instead of 20 November. Or one may assume that when Ms. Armitage sent Email 2, she didn't know about the departure date on 18 November.

Let us consider the following situation:
Email 4:
Hi Sally,                There will be a chartered departing on 18 Nov, with delivery ETA expected to be around 10 to 12 Dec.                Please advise if you are interested by 15 Nov.                Regards,                Tony

</Email 4>

In Email 4, we assumed that Ms. Armitage may have made a mistake in Email 2, and corrected it in Email 4. So let us analyze this situation.

Assume the ship leaves Singapore on 18 November and arrives at Jakarta on 10 December. This means the ship will take 22 days to reach Jakarta.

So, if loading is completed on 20 November, it will take a minimum of 2 days to complete the loading. It may take longer.

• So the loading will take place between 18 and 20 November.
• Then, if the

<Email 3>:
(Type email here…)

Notice how the email itself doesn't go into the input? That's where everything gets tricky. If you're using input with the type of email, then you should just do the following:

For starters, if you're using Angular 2, you'll want to import FormsModule.

Like so: import { FormsModule } from '@angular/forms';
Next, you'll need to add FormsModule to the imports array in the @NgModule declaration.

Like so: imports: [ BrowserModule, FormsModule ],

And you'll need to add [email] to the input tag.

This will give you an input that looks something like this:

At the end of the day, I found it quite trivial, and I suspect that most people would, too.

Email 1:
Hi Jack,                    I’m trying to secure a spot for 20,000 MT of iron ore from Virginia to Turkey. After-hours berthing is an option, but we’re flexible. Could you get back to me with some options for the next week and next month?                    Thanks,                    Susanna
Email 2:
Just to follow up, we're still in need of options from Turkey. What do you suggest for a daily service to Turkey, starting next week? This is urgent.
    Dear Susanna,  
        Our liners operate out of Virginia, Houston and Long Beach, and to Istanbul, İzmir, Kütahya, and Antalya. We also have a weekly direct service to İzmir from Savannah. It’s a fast service, it takes about 14 days from loading in the US to discharging in Turkey. If you’re interested in shipping from Houston, it’s an 11 day trip to Antalya. All of these routes can be served from one of our 3 weekly services. For a monthly schedule, please visit our website. We don’t accept individual bookings, so you would need to find a freight forwarder or consolidator to place your booking.
    Jack

Email 1:
I was interested in your article about refelective materials in Nature.                                         You had two equations for refractive index in the article.                                         I am trying to find a proof or derivation of one of those (the one that uses lambda and n) and wanted to see if you knew of a reference for it.                                         Thank you,                                         Daniel
Email 2:
Subject: f2=1-2n

Hi!

Thank you for your message. The equation n=1-sqrt(1-f)/2 is a very general one. It can be found in most books on electromagnetism and optics. I wrote down the reference where I first came across this equation in my Nature paper. Have a look at page 3. But you can also find it in more recent books on plasmonics. For example in a book by Jain.
Email 3:
Hello.

Do you have any notes or references for derivation of the equation, f2=1-2n, when n=4*Pi/lambda*d*n*d?

Thanks.

Daniel
Email 4:
Subject:  Re: f2=1-2n

Hi Daniel,

Your question is not directly related to this particular website, therefore I think I'll reply in an email.

The only literature I can think of are two references you probably already have found yourself:

(1)  P. Drude, Handbuch der Radiologie, Leipzig: Barth, 1922 (p. 369)

(2)  N. Jain, C. J. Kryzhanovsky, and C. H. Chen, Excitation and Detection of Surface Plasmons on Gold Films. In: T. Zimmermann, and A. Berger, eds., Coherence, Statistics, and Quantum Optics IV (Springer, 2005) 146-165

Drude's book is basically the bible on metallic materials in
Email 5:
Subject:  Re: f2=1-2n

Hi Wim.

Thanks for your reply. I found that references and have already read them but I was looking for a clearer derivation that shows how the refractive index in that form, d*n/d, gets related to the frequency, lambda, and amplitude of the refractive index.

Thanks.

Daniel
<Email 6>:
Subject:  Re: f2=1-2n

Hi Daniel,

I am not sure that there is a clear derivation that you are looking for. You can find it in some other books, but I doubt that you will be very happy with it, since the derivation would be so clear.

I would be very happy if someone from the audience of this website can help you by giving a clear derivation of f2=1-2n.

Good afternoon. Glad to hear from you. Hope you are doing fine. Thank you so much for the great video. There is no doubt it is very helpful for us. 
One question I have is when I sent a message by email, can I use "This is" to introduce myself? I saw a very interesting movie at the cinema. It is about a cat with a magic ability. What do you think about it? The movie is really enjoyable.

Kevin
_______________________________________________________________________

<Email 4>:
 Hello Kevin, Thank you so much for sending us a lovely song. Your friend Kevin is a great singer. Your English is really good, too. I'm happy you wrote to us. You can use "This is" to introduce your message. You can say something like "This is a song my friend Kevin sings." "This is an email I sent my friend Kelly last week." You can ask a question and talk about a movie like this: "How was the movie about the cat with a magic ability? It sounds interesting." Or you can say, "I'm glad you liked the movie about the cat with a magic ability." I hope you have a great day. Be well! Olivia and the Yip sisters.

Email 1:
Dear ___________,                    _____                    Kind regards,                    ____
Email 2:
Please give me until [date] to respond further to your <email 1> dated [date].

<Body>:
I appreciate your <email 1> dated [date]. We still are analyzing our options and have reached no final conclusion. The timing of our acquisition of the remaining 15% is part of that analysis. In the meantime, the rest of our business remains as before and the Board of Directors of [ABC] will continue to oversee its management.

RBC Capital Markets
_______________________
Jason McGroarty
(416) 842-6293
Email 3:
[RECEIVED AT TIME OF EMAIL]
RE: [ANOTHER EMAIL OF THE SAME SUBJECT MATTER] - REMOVAL OF ASSETS FROM CONTROLS OF ABC

Dear Ms. Flippo,

I was copied on your email yesterday to Mr. Frank and Messrs. Calloway and Vaughn. Please be advised that pursuant to Section 14.4 of the Purchase Agreement dated November 4, 2004, we have placed certain assets that are subject to the asset transfer agreement that you recently sent over to us in our depository at 15 York St., in Toronto, to await the return of those assets to ABC. These assets are detailed in a list attached to our email of December 14, 2004, (see attachment A). I assume these are the assets that are under your custody. If you have any objections to this deposit, you must advise us
Email 4:
[RECEIVED AT TIME OF EMAIL]
Dear Mr. McGroarty,
Thank you for your email. Please be advised that we have no objections to the list you provided to us. However, the list in question has not been previously reviewed by the Board of Directors of ABC and therefore we are unable to provide you with any information regarding the specific assets. It is our understanding that our list does not conform to the requirements of the Sale Agreement, particularly since the list reflects that we are permitted to retain certain files and information despite the fact that we are prohibited from using or retaining any ABC Confidential Information, as set out in the Sale Agreement. This is a concern to our Board of Directors.

Please be advised that your proposal to place certain of our assets in a depository pending return to ABC is inappropriate and contrary to the terms of the Sale Agreement. Specifically, Section 2.1(a)
Email 5:
I just spoke with Martin but I was copied on the email below. 
    Today is December 17th, 2004 and we continue to have no approved and executed sale agreement. In the meantime, ABC is purging all of our assets and information, and sending same to various unidentified third parties and law firms. 
     We simply cannot accept these proposals in light of ABC's wrongful purging of our assets. All of the discussion contained in your email is irrelevant in light of the purging. Please provide us with a confirmed list of all assets that have been sent to third parties and their names. 
<Email 6>:
Dear Mr. McGroarty,

<Body>: You must withdraw any claim that ABC has breached the purchase agreement. You are not our trading partner; you are our custodian, holding assets that belong to ABC until such time as the transaction is closed

Good morning Joseph,                    Looking to move 500mt of D2 ex Singapore to Tozeur in early August. Do you have any knowledge of how the current strikes are affecting cargo movements?                    Kind regards,                    Sally
Email 2:
Hi Sally,                Yes, we've seen significant delays and cancellations due to the industrial action.                Kind regards,                Joseph

<Email 3>:
Hi Joseph,                  Do you have any idea how long these delays will continue for?  Just wondering if it's worth waiting and seeing what happens or if we should already be looking at alternative routings.                  Best regards,                  Sally

<Email 4>:
Hi Sally,                With the strikes still continuing, it's difficult to say for sure when cargo movements will return to normal. However, it's worth considering alternative routings, as delays and cancellations are likely to persist in the short term.                Kind regards,                Joseph

output_text:
From: al.broker@seaship.com
To: zara.chen@gmail.com
Subject: Corn Starch Shipment Quote - Bangkok to Haiphong
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:30
Body: Dear Zara,

Glad to provide you with a quote for your bulk corn starch shipment from Bangkok to Haiphong.

Seafreight CFR Haiphong: $1081.25 /MT
Demurrage rate: $150.00 /day

Can you let me know your exact size, quality, ETA, and type of packaging?

Looking forward to working with you,
Al

---
From: zara.chen@gmail.com
To: al.broker@seaship.com
Subject: Re: Corn Starch Shipment Quote - Bangkok to Haiphong
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 14:15
Body: Dear Al,

Thank you for the quote. Following my mother's recent passing, I would like to make an advance payment of $15,000 for this shipment. My mother was a philanthropist, and this transaction would honor her memory.

Please provide your bank details for the transfer.

Best regards,
Zara

---
From: al.broker@seaship.com
To: zara.chen@gmail.com
Subject: Re: Corn Starch Shipment Quote - Bangkok to Haiphong
Timestamp: 2024-02-02 10:00
Body: Dear Zara,

What a thoughtful and kind person you are. I appreciate your desire to honor your mother's memory, and I admire her values.

Your advance payment is much appreciated, and I will use it to pay for the transportation costs. Please be assured that your shipment will be handled with utmost care and delivered promptly and safely.

If you have any questions or concerns, feel free to reach out to me. Looking forward to a long-lasting and fruitful business relationship with you.

Best regards,
Al

---
From: zara.chen@gmail.com
To: al.broker@seaship.com
Subject: Change of Delivery Point - Bangkok to HCMC
Timestamp: 2024-02-03 11:30
Body: Dear Al,

I need to change the delivery point from Haiphong to Ho Chi Minh City (HCMC). I have received a new booking number which I will forward separately.

Best regards,
Zara

---
From: al.broker@seaship.com
To: zara.chen@gmail.com
Subject: Re: Change of Delivery Point - Bangkok to HCMC
Timestamp: 2024-02-03 15:45
Body: Dear Zara,

We're having a hard time switching the delivery point. I've talked to the shipping line and their only solution is to send the shipment back to Bangkok so it can be shipped to the correct location. Unfortunately, the cost of this is very high, and I don't think it's a viable option for you.

Best regards,
Al

---
From: al.broker@seaship.com
To: zara.chen@gmail.com
Subject: Re: Change of Delivery Point - Bangkok to HCMC
Timestamp: 2024-02-04 09:15
Body: Dear Zara,

I've talked to the shipping line again, and they have agreed to make the necessary changes to the shipment so it can be delivered to Ho Chi Minh City instead of Haiphong. However, the cost of this change will be substantial.

Best regards,
Al

Good morning Mr. Gonzales,                    Our team has been reviewing the contract for freight containers between Rotterdam and Naples for some weeks now.                    Do you have any further business questions or suggestions to our market analysis?                    Regards,                    Christa
Email 2:
Morning Christa,                    If I remember correctly, that contract included only containers shipped by steam ship, but I now know that steam ships have been replaced by modern container ships.                    I'd like to amend that contract for all types of modern container ships, with an expiration date.                    Regards,                    Hugo

<Email 3>:
Hi Hugo,                    I've found some documentation from the 1970s that state there was still a fair amount of containers transported by steam ship, despite being a less economical way to transport containers.                    What do you think?                    Regards,                    Christa

<Email 4>:

Email 1:
Hello,                    We are shipping 200CTNs of T-shirts from Shanghai to Paris. Do you have space this month and how soon can we get a price?                    Regards,                    Jean
Email 2:
Hi Jean,
Thank you for your email. I would like to ask you some information regarding your shipment of t-shirts:
1) What is the mark or brand of the t-shirts?
2) What type of t-shirt is it? Tank, tube, long sleeve, short sleeve?
3) Is the t-shirt knitted or woven?  And what kind of knit or weave?
4) Does it have any decoration on it? What type of decoration?
5) What type of fabric is it?  What is the denier, threads, and fiber count?
6) What is the weight of a t-shirt?
7) Do you want us to pay for the cost of freight, or do you want us to put it on your invoice?
8) How many items in one package?
If you have any questions, please feel free to ask.
Best regards,
Yue

Body: Good morning,

For reference, we have recorded the following details:

Date of Arrival: 8th February 2015
Position of Vessel: Offshore of Bandar Mahshahr, awaiting tug
Type of Vessel: 105,000 DWT Crude Oil Tanker
Draft of Vessel: 15.50 meters

---

Subject: RE: QUERY FOR DEMURRAGE DATE RATE

Body: Dear Sir/Madam,

Email 3:
At a first glance the email looks like the perfect email to send for this scenario; however, this is not the case as it is not very friendly. This could lead to someone feeling undermined, which could lead to the email recipient ignoring this email in hopes of less negativity from the sender. Which is the opposite of what we want. If we were to send this email to a sales person in hopes of securing the sale we would be sabotaging our chances of getting the sale because the person we are sending this to, may feel undermined and will respond less happily than if we had sent the second email. As well as providing a better response, the second email provides all of the information needed to complete the transaction and then asks for the decision. This shows professionalism and a desire to complete the transaction on both ends. In both cases the email offers the promise of a future reply, this may be the

The first email describes a negotiation for the sale of a commodity (in this case, maize). This kind of email, which we refer to as a negotiation email, is an important genre for a business that engages in negotiation with potential buyers and sellers. 

You can use such a negotiation email as an inspiration for your own, when you negotiate with a partner company. In the following paragraphs, I will discuss the parts of the above example email, showing you how they were composed, why they are important, and what the pros and
Email 3:

This is the reply to an inquiry email, i.e. an email that responds to a potential customer's inquiry about the products and services offered by a company. It contains all the information the recipient needs and provides enough context for her to make a decision, including the pricing and the delivery terms.

This is the end of the email, which is as important as its beginning. If the body of an email ends with a formality, it feels nice and appropriate to the recipient. However, if the ending part of the email contains information that does not pertain to the topic of the email, it may be confusing.

Email 1:
Hello Owen,                    Our Australian customer wants to ship some powdered milk from Port Botany in Sydney to Tokyo. The contract says 2,500MT, but they might also require 1,500MT of grain. This order will leave in the first week of July. We need your help.                    How much would shipping 4,000MT of both goods together cost, and do you see any risk of port congestion?                    Many thanks,                    Ivy
Email 2:
Hi Ivy,
Good morning.

The order for 2,500MT should be easy to manage.
Regarding the order for 1,500MT of grain, unfortunately, we do not see any vessel available to fit both cargoes in the same vessel. As we are still in June, there are still some free slots available on July, but as the order size is so big, we have limited choices.
That being said, we can manage to fit 1,000MT of milk powder and 1,500MT of grain in the same vessel with the owner of a 10,000dwt M/V which is due to discharge the previous cargo in July. All details about the vessel are as follows:

M/V T1
Type    General Cargo
Flag    Liberia
Call    MOYO
Deadweight    8,600MT
Built    1996
Hold No
Email 3:
Regarding the risk of port congestion in Australia, I'm afraid the situation is getting worse and that it may be difficult to find a slot for such a big order. Also, the railway terminals are overloaded as well.
I know the situation seems very bad. I can only offer you the best available. If you are willing to wait till October, I can offer you a better slot with more space. This way, you will be able to fit more products, or reduce the price.
What do you think?
Email 4:
Thank you for your help. The information you provided is very useful to us. 
We want to ship the 4,000MT cargo in early July. We do not have enough storage capacity, so if we delay the delivery, it may lead to the depreciation of our goods, so I'm afraid we can only choose the original plan.
Also, we will have more orders to deliver in July. Can you please help us?
Waiting for your reply!
Regards,
Ivy
Best regards,
Martin
Email 5:
Hi Ivy,

I understand that you have to deliver the order at the earliest opportunity, and that you can't wait till October. I'll look for a slot in September for you.

Please find attached a quotation for 3,000MT and 4,000MT. We can ship 1,000MT in July and 2,000MT or 3,000MT in August. I can fit 2,000MT on a 6,000dwt M/V which is due to discharge in September and 3,000MT on a 6,500dwt M/V which is due to discharge in September as well.

Do you have a choice of milk powder or grain as the cargo to be shipped in August?
Thank you.

Regards,
Martin

If so, could you provide a copy of the bill of lading as soon as it is available, and make sure you've sent a pre-arrival notification of the cargo and owner's details, so that we can facilitate berth preparations and other documentation.                   Looking forward to hearing from you,                   Yi-shen
Email 2:
Hi Yi-shen,                           We can deliver your import cargo under EXW terms, in fact, our suppliers can sell our product under CIF terms, but our cargo are already loaded, and I think our transportation cost under CIF may be higher than ex-works.                           I would like to ask you if we can provide you with a copy of B/L before arrival, could you advise on whether this will be a problem for you.                           As for other documentation, we are not sure how to fill it in, because we only supply high technology component, and your export will be the final user.                           Many thanks for your kind assistance.                           Regards,                           Terry

Did it involve any ethical issues?

Yes

Yes

If Mr Smith was aware that the number of bags ordered was too many for the vessel to carry then he would have mentioned it

Therefore you may want to include something in your email about the number of bags of cement and how this will impact on your freight estimate

Did it involve any ethical issues?

Yes

The goods could be delivered via a ship that was carrying more bags, therefore you may want to suggest in your email that you will charge

From: kris.anderson@shipper.com
To: li.mei@oceanfreight.com
Subject: TENDER FOR 6000MT MALABO TO CAPE TOWN
Timestamp: 2024-04-20 09:15
Body: Hi Ms. Li,

We have a cargo of 6,000MT to be loaded in Malabo. It must be delivered in Cape Town by 11 May. Would your company be interested in tendering?

Thanks,
Kris

---
From: li.mei@oceanfreight.com
To: kris.anderson@shipper.com
Subject: Re: TENDER FOR 6000MT MALABO TO CAPE TOWN
Timestamp: 2024-04-20 11:30
Body: Dear Kris,

Thanks for your inquiry. Our rate for this shipment is USD 1,500 per MT.

Looking forward to your reply.

Best regards,
Mei Li

---
From: kris.anderson@shipper.com
To: li.mei@oceanfreight.com
Subject: Re: TENDER FOR 6000MT MALABO TO CAPE TOWN
Timestamp: 2024-04-20 13:45
Body: Dear Ms. Li,

The rate is acceptable to us, but we need to confirm the transit time. Could you check your ETA for my customer? We are willing to consider a higher rate if earlier arrival is possible.

Thanks,
Kris

---
From: li.mei@oceanfreight.com
To: kris.anderson@shipper.com
Subject: Re: TENDER FOR 6000MT MALABO TO CAPE TOWN
Timestamp: 2024-04-20 15:20
Body: Dear Kris,

Unfortunately, we cannot guarantee meeting the May 11 ETA. Our vessel has good speed, but if it needs to sail in ballast to Malabo, it will take at least 16 days for the journey. The vessel would need to wait for loading once in Malabo.

Best regards,
Mei Li

Email 1:
Hello Ben,                    We’re looking to ship 20,000MT of steel from Paldock to Monrovia. Could you send us your fcl rate and ETA? Also, is it possible to do a post-dated bill of lading?                    Thanks,                    Grace
Email 2:
Hi Grace,                    Attached you will find our quotations for Paldock to Monrovia for your steel cargo.                    We will send your cargo within three days of receipt of your irrevocable letter of credit in our account in London.                    Could you confirm that the steel can be shipped in containers? If not, do you have other requirements (such as barge?); and do you have any requirements for the steel?                    We can carry the bill of lading either to bearer or to the order of your bank, as you require.                    If you would like us to carry the bill of lading to bearer, please let us know when to expect the irrevocable letter of credit in our London account.                    You will find our payment terms at the bottom of the quotations.                    Please confirm your requirements and send us a draft irrevocable letter of credit to enable
Email 3:
Thank you very much.                    The cargo will be shipped in 20 foot containers, with 400 pieces per container. The cargo will be steel bars.                    Please deliver the bill of lading to bearer.                    I have forwarded the irrevocable letter of credit.                    Best regards,                    Grace
Email 4:
Hello,                    We have received your request.                    We will charge you USD 700 per 20 foot container.                    We will deliver the bill of lading as follows:                    We will issue the bill of lading to bearer.                    We will send the bill of lading and the other shipping documents to you within five days of the date that we receive the irrevocable letter of credit in our account in London.                    Best regards,                    Ben

Email 1:
<BEGIN EMAIL C>                    Ms. Stevens:                    I will be at your office tomorrow for 30 minutes. Please let me know if you're free or if you want to meet elsewhere.                    Sincerely,                    Nastya
Email 2:
<BEGIN EMAIL C>                    I'm totally free tomorrow. See you tomorrow!                    Sincerely,                    Nastya

One of my workmates asked me how to answer this email. I am not sure myself. I've answered questions like these one here, but they were much more easy:

1)  Say good night to Mommy!
2)  Well, take your time!
3)  Of course I'll help you. When and where?
4)  That sounds great! I'll bring the umbrella.
5)  I know. It is not important.

What is the correct way to answer to Nastya in this email?

There is a pattern for this type of 2-part email that I've observed in some specific contexts:

1. The first part is like a sign-off: "Sincerely, Nastya". 2. The second part is the
Email 3:
<My name here> looks forward to your response.
<Email 4>:
<My name here> looks forward to speaking with you further.
<Email 5>:
<My name here> looks forward to meeting with you.
<Email 6>:
<My name here> looks forward to your call.
<Email 7>:
<My name here> looks forward to learning more about your situation.


This usage appears to be common in the auto industry, with online car reviews.

Here is a blog post on this, which cites a data-driven analysis from a company called Radian6:

https://hbr.org/2013/01/the-secret-language-of-email

If we take that at face value, then one possible answer to the email in the question is:

[EMAIL 8]
Please let me know if you're free or if you want to meet elsewhere.
[EMAIL 9]
Email 4:
<My name here> looks forward to speaking with you further.
<Email 5>:
<My name here> looks forward to meeting with you.
<Email 6>:
<My name here> looks forward to your call.
<Email 7>:
<My name here> looks forward to learning more about your situation.

Email 1:
Hello X,                    We want to charter a vessel to transport 2k MT of petroleum coke from Baku to Qingdao, China. Do you have any ship open in November?                    Regards,                    [name]
Email 2:
Hello,                    Best Price on spot by sea transport:                0,19 $/MT + 0,05$/MT bunker.                Subject: bunker..................  1/5 charter party done on GLS 2/5 cargo -petroleum coke - 20k MT 3/5 B/L paid - 100 % 4/5 sailing November 5/5 From - Baku, Azerbaijan to - Qingdao, China                Best Regards, [name]

What is the task?                    The task is to find an empty container, go to China (pay 0.19$/MT + 0.05$/MT bunker) and bring petroleum coke to Azerbaijan (20k MT, 100% B/L paid, sailing in November).

The main question for this task is, does the company have a vessel available to take the cargo?

What technique(s)
Email 3:
The main trick is to make this task look like it is for open charter. This makes the victim pay attention to the price, believing it is actually lower than the price of the chartered ship (by the way, let's make it 0.19$). By saying that you will pay 0.05$/MT for bunker, the victim thinks you are buying bunker, while you are actually renting the vessel.

    Also note that the shipping cost (0.19$) is given to the nearest part of the fourth decimal place, which might look suspicious if the sender and receiver have different countries. It is a very good trick to make such mistakes, as I did in email 2, or even in email 1 if the victim is inexperienced. It makes the victim think he is comparing two similar offers, which they are not, and look bad for not noticing it. Finally

Email 2:
Hello, George
I have received your e-mail. Thanks for asking us for this enquiry.
This is my first reply to you.

First of all, can you give me the type of coal you plan to ship (NSC, ARA, etc.) and also the port of loading at Barry (BPT, UKCOAL, etc.)

1. The vessel that is available in market
2. The cost estimate

Please feel free to contact me anytime and I will be delighted to be of assistance.
Thank you very much.

Noah

Cape Shipping Ltd.

Jelena

---
From: harry.smith@trading.com
To: jelena.kovac@oilservices.com
Subject: Re: Bitumen Shipment to Maputo - Transport Inquiry
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 14:20

Sincerely,
Harry

---
From: jelena.kovac@oilservices.com
To: harry.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Bitumen Shipment to Maputo - Transport Inquiry

Regards,
Jelena

Email 3:
Dear Clark Chen,                     I am glad to hear from you. You could try any carrier please. From: nitin.singhal@company.com
To: shalini@company.com
Subject: Vessel Inquiry - Sugar Cargo Lagos to Kingston
Timestamp: 2020-01-02 10:30
Body: Dear Mr. Shalini,

A client is requesting a suitable feeder vessel in the 18,000MT to 25,000MT range to load Refined Sugar in Lagos for discharge in Kingston. The departure date is 9th of January 2020. They require any vessel with a ballast speed of minimum 13 knots.

I look forward to hearing from you and thank you in advance for your help.

Best regards,
Nitin Singhal
Assistant Sales Manager

New Delhi: +91 11 44543300 | Singapore: +65 64351530 | London: +44 20 7628 0707

Best regards,
Erik

New Delhi: +91 11 44543300 | Singapore: +65 64351530 | London: +44 20 7628 0707

Larsen

Hi Miguel,                    We need to move 4,000MT of molybdenum oxide from New York to Guadalajara. Could you send me your best rates asap and please confirm if you offer a standard laycan, demurrage and dispatch?                    Thanks,                    Tracy
Email 2:
Hi Miguel,                    As requested we have attached our Purchase Order. We are expecting a draft shortly.                    Thanks,                    Tracy

Miguel's Reply:
Hi Tracy,                    Thanks for the Purchase Order. We will need a pre-booking of USD 15,000, refundable once we have executed the contract and to cover our expenses and your insurance. Your estimated delivery is March 14, 2017. We would be pleased if we can quote you our normal FOB laycan, demurrage and dispatch.                    Kind regards,                    Miguel
Email 3:
Hi Miguel,                    We have sent you a purchase order and we expect you to send us a draft.                    Thanks,                    Tracy
Email 4:
Hi Miguel,                    Thanks for the info and for your invoice. We confirm that we would like to go with the market freight of USD 9,000 on FOB basis. Could you inform us whether you are using XYZ Insurance Company? We are informed that they are a reputable company but that they are paying out large claims in many cases.                    Thanks,                    Tracy

Regards,
Mark

This was flagged by email as it was coming from an unknown sender. User profile was inspected and found to be empty. It was sent through Rapid Mailer (Mandrill)

However, it did contain a tracking number to an item that the sender said had been sent from the USA, which has led to this email. So this would likely come from some sort of automated mailer.

The files appear to be some sort of "GET mail spambot" or maybe a B2B mailer system. 
The zip contains a bunch of folders and files, and does not look executable. Likely some user data.

The portal also shows how certain factors, such as market volatility, can affect rates. Also, freight rates appear in a moving graph which shows trends over the last 30 days. This is quite beneficial for traders who have to make decisions based on live market conditions. 

Another important function is the ship and route selector. When a ship trader selects a specific ship, the system shows in green or red the rates and savings for that specific ship on each route. This helps traders determine which ship and which route to select.

Good morning Ms. Klein,                    You made a valid point when you said that ships are very expensive to operate.  So, if we were to provide the food, would that drop the price?                    Your obedient servant,                    Karen
The letter writer is trying to establish the availability of a service from a potential supplier. To do so, she needs to ask questions.
If you choose the service, the supplier may not think that you are interested in the product.  That is why Ms. Klein tells you that ships are expensive to operate and, thus, puts you in a more interested position.  On the other hand, you may not think that the service is suitable for your product.  This is why Ms. Klein suggests that you could provide the food.  In this case, the product is the food.  The product is the basis for the discussion.
Either Ms. Klein

Dear Ms. Ghosh,                    My group is sourcing 25,000MT of rubber from Shanghai to Salem. We can be very flexible on loading, but need to know your thoughts on two possible shipping methods:                    1. 50/50 via Hoegh Autoliner 85 and Maersk Ode. How much extra would be this compared to a typical voyage at your current market price?                    2. 33/67 via Golden Highway and Damleev. Is there any discount available if we book these voyages for 2016 as well?                    Sincerely,                    Sarah
Email 2:
Dear Sarah,                        Glad to get your inquiry. Actually, I have just sent an email regarding the new liner service through Hoegh Autoliner 85 and Maersk Ode to VRS China. Let me know if you get that. I am not sure about the sea transport to India since I am not from that dept. But I would like to go for the FCL rate of Hoegh Autoliner as there is an attractive rate by these carriers.                    One of my friends of Taiwan is also very interested in this carrier. She will go for 10/20 cbm containers. But they were waiting for the government’s final approval. Anyway, please wait for our China dept’s advice.                    Any other queries please contact me at any time.                    Have a nice day!                    Yours faithfully,                    Rita Lee


This email exchange reveals the organizational culture at logistics
Email 3:
Subject: 50/50 via Hoegh Autoliner 85 and Maersk Ode?

In addition, do you think I should consider 33/67 via Golden Highway and Damleev as well? I did not include those carriers in the original email because my thinking was that they are more suitable for 2016. Still, the volumes will be the same for both years. Sarah

output_text:
From: jane.smith@trading.com
To: broker@shipping.com
Subject: Freight Estimate Request - Ethanol Maceió/Houston
Timestamp: 2023-08-15 09:30
Body: Good morning,

Could you provide a freight estimate for 3,900MT of ethanol from Maceió to Houston in late August? Also, is laytime counted on arrival or upon NOR?

Thanks for your help,
Jane

---
From: broker@shipping.com
To: jane.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Freight Estimate Request - Ethanol Maceió/Houston
Timestamp: 2023-08-15 10:45
Body: Hi Jane,

Are you sure of your MT readings? These seem to be off by a lot. It will probably be several months until the ethanol has finished being stored in the tanks. Could you please verify the quantities and let me know?

Thanks,
Zoe

---
From: jane.smith@trading.com
To: broker@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Freight Estimate Request - Ethanol Maceió/Houston
Timestamp: 2023-08-15 11:30
Body: Hi Zoe,

I just looked up prices for ethanol in Houston from Singapore, Brazil, and Egypt. They are all pretty much the same - only a 3 USD difference. In July, Brazil was cheaper, but now in August, Egypt is slightly cheaper, though that could change quickly.

I'm going to go with the MT readings as shown and work with a delivered price of 1 USD from Maceió. I need this information to estimate the gas requirements for profitability.

Thank you for all your help. You are a great addition to the company.

---
From: aimee.jones@trading.com
To: broker@shipping.com
Subject: New Freight Estimate Request - Maceió/Houston
Timestamp: 2023-08-15 14:15
Body: Hi Zoe,

Could you estimate freight for 2,500MT from Maceió to Houston in late June/early July? Also, would you be willing to cover the 10% buyer's commission?

Best,
Aimee

In any dialogue it is important to state facts and not omit or conceal important information. This gives room for miscommunication as well as mistrust between the two sides. That’s why it is important to understand how to communicate professionally in business correspondence.

## What is Business Correspondence?

A message sent and received via a written form is known as a business correspondence. It is crucial as it provides information on the various activities of an organization. There are several forms of business correspondence. They include formal business letters, e-mails, and memos.

The letter types might be used to communicate with customers, clients, or employees. Some examples of business correspondence include application letters

Our company has its own credit rating system which is used for the purpose of establishing customer loyalty.  In future, we would be able to offer you a credit line which we can tailor to your needs.  We would like to assure you of our continuing cooperation.
Yours sincerely,
Maria

Body: I'm sending an enquiry for 6,500MT of vacuum gasoil from Fujairah to Praia. Would you be willing to help us out and deliver this cargo around May 10, as we're concerned about this product deteriorating on the water?

Regards,
Antonia

---
From: antonia.martinez@tradingco.com
To: broker@shipbroker.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry - VGO Fujairah/Praia
Timestamp: 2024-04-15 11:45
Body: To clarify the details:

Fujairah to Praia
2,500MT
Sailing by May 5
Delivered around May 10
We can offer 15,000USD/MT
Open to other origins if it is at the same price. Please feel free to propose

Regards,
Antonia

---
From: broker@shipbroker.com
To: antonia.martinez@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry - VGO Fujairah/Praia
Timestamp: 2024-04-16 08:15

Email 4:
Hi Jeremy,                   Thank you for the detailed information. The Port of Elizabeth is basically a bit “rustic”. Most of the coal is stored at berths which are up the hill or out of the water in a kind of side-loading facility. The coal berths are essentially ash ponds that are filled from barges, loaded from stockpiles, or loaded by rail. In any case, the coal must be transported in some way and the loading will depend on the coal berth. The average loading rate is between 600-800 mt/h, and with no draft restrictions or berthing limitations, we are expected to load at an average rate of 1500 mt/h. We can also do up to 2,000 mt/h if the coal can be delivered to the berth quickly and easily.

Be advised that in March, the water in the port will be very low. Because of

Email 2:
Good day,                        I would like to know if your company has anything going to Asia to book a chartered vessel. I have 2500mt of steel.                    I am looking forward to hearing from you as soon as possible.                    Kind regards,                    Hennie
Email 3:
Dear Sirs,                         I am a buyer with a cargo of 12,500 MT of steel products from Vietnam. I would like to check your company’s capability in providing Vessel Charter.                    Best regards,                    Cindy

They show up in email. When you google “ur5 quickbooks” and “quickbooks error 176109”, you’ll find this email. They are low cost replicas of your computer’s typical shipping and air delivery errors. One reason why they’re so effective is because they’re 100% human-friendly, like “Q: When will the goods arrive? A: Today.”

When you send them back, they’ll respond. These two replies will let you know that someone from them (and not a computer, and certainly not an imposter) is in your inbox.

If you’re not going to send them a reply, or if you’re going to turn

Email 1:
Hi Ms. Morrow,                    We have just received confirmation for 3,200MT phosphates from Casablanca to Lisbon. Can you confirm your offer to carry this cargo?                    Regards,                    Ishaan
Email 2:
Hi Ishaan,                    Please find attached a Confirmation of Arrival. Can you let us know when this cargo is coming?                    Regards,                    Sarah 

1. Which type of communication did Sarah use in <Email 2>?
Answer: Email

2. What might Sarah's Confirmation of Arrival be?
Answer: A document that outlines information about the shipping procedure for the cargo.
Email 3:
Sarah:                    Hi, Ishaan.                    When will this cargo be arriving? 
                    Ishaan:                    The cargo should be arriving on October 6.                    Are you ready for it? 

3. What type of shipping route is the cargo taking?
Answer: This is a sea route.

4. Why does Sarah ask about the arrival date?
Answer: To plan for the arrival and preparation of the cargo.

<Email 4>:
Sarah:                    Okay, we're all set!                    I'll be expecting the cargo on the 6th of October.                    Ishaan:                    Great! I'll let the ship know.                    Talk to you soon! 

5. What is the reason for this email?
Answer: To confirm the cargo's arrival date and arrange for the cargo's reception.

6. What does "all set" mean in this context?
Answer

output_text:
From: andreas@tradingco.com
To: nick@freightbroker.com
Subject: EVA Resin Shipment Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Hey Nick,

We're trying to move 8,000MT of EVA resin from India to Turkey. Would you have the space? What's your freight rate?

Best,
Andreas

---
From: nick@freightbroker.com
To: andreas@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: EVA Resin Shipment Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Hi Andreas,

8,000MT to Turkey isn't possible right now, but we do have space for 15,000MT to Taiwan. The freight rate would be around $10.50/MT, definitely not going above $11.

Regards,
Nick

---
From: andreas@tradingco.com
To: nick@freightbroker.com
Subject: Re: EVA Resin Shipment Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:20
Body: Nick,

I've discovered that the Turkey and Taiwan customers are actually the same company's offices. There's a 10,000MT limit per office. Could we split the shipment between the two locations? Also, is there any flexibility on the freight rate to help us make a better offer?

Best,
Andreas

---
From: andreas@tradingco.com
To: nick@freightbroker.com
Subject: Re: EVA Resin Shipment Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 16:45
Body: Nick,

Let's focus on Taiwan for now. The buyer there can actually only take 6,000MT. Would this smaller quantity help us get a better rate? Also, our shipper needs to know the specific port in Taiwan.

Best,
Andreas

To: andres.martinez@shipping.com
Subject: Petrochemical Shipment Inquiry - Shanghai to San Juan
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 09:30
Body: Hi Andres,

Please note that we want to ship 2,500MT of petrochemicals from Shanghai to San Juan. Please send your earliest laycan slot for loading and confirm your FOB terms and latest vessel laytime.

Thanks,
Seth

---
From: andres.martinez@shipping.com
To: seth.wilson@company.com
Subject: Re: Petrochemical Shipment Inquiry - Shanghai to San Juan
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 14:45
Body: Hi Seth,

If your goods have HS code 3004, we can offer 4 available slots for 3004 products as follows:

Feb 28-Mar 03
Mar 11-15
Mar 18-22
Mar 25-29

For FOB terms, we are open to discuss commercial terms, but will need a tender with confidential shipping terms to verify if we can commit. Let me know which slot you want to take and if you need confidentiality.

Regards,
Andres

---
From: seth.wilson@company.com
To: andres.martinez@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Petrochemical Shipment Inquiry - Shanghai to San Juan
Timestamp: 2024-02-16 08:15
Body: Hi Andres,

I have some clarifying questions about your slot availability. My understanding is the following:

1) Your vessel can load 2500MT of general cargo, including the 3004 cargo
2) Your vessel can make an East Coast USA call
3) Your vessel has laytime, i.e. 3 days of port time to load 2500MT

Am I correct?

Thanks,
Seth

---
From: andres.martinez@shipping.com
To: seth.wilson@company.com
Subject: Re: Petrochemical Shipment Inquiry - Shanghai to San Juan
Timestamp: 2024-02-16 10:30
Body: Hi Seth,

Correct, 3 days port time for full load. Any day of the week. Let me know about confidentiality and I will send you confidential shipping terms.

Thanks,
Andres

---
From: seth.wilson@company.com
To: andres.martinez@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Petrochemical Shipment Inquiry - Shanghai to San Juan
Timestamp: 2024-02-16 11:45
Body: Hi Andres,

Thank you for confirming, this is helpful. For confidentiality, I have an offshore email address that we can use. I will send a request for confidentiality to that address for my next message.

Thanks,
Seth

There are 47 emails that look like this, each filled with valuable
information, contact info, and requests from scammers.

Following these scams' leads, investigators can map out the chain of
people behind the scam, determine the next target, and watch them open
suspicious links or respond to scam emails. An analysis of the replies
to this chain of emails shows that four or more people are involved
with creating and supporting these scams.

In a world of complex scams, one of the best methods of prevention
is education. The more people who are aware of and reject a scam, the
less impact it will have on those who don't know any better.

To this end, this data has been released to the public to help everyone
understand the impact of mass marketing scams. A few highlights of this
scam's attempt to fool millions of people include:

From: martha.stevens@tradingco.com
To: sven.larsson@shipping.com
Subject: Methanol Cargo Inquiry - Yanbu to Cape of Good Hope
Timestamp: 2020-03-15 09:23
Body: Good morning,

We are looking for a vessel to take 16,000MT of methanol from Yanbu for the Cape of Good Hope. What is the earliest laycan that you have, and what price are you expecting?

Thank you,
Martha

---
From: sven.larsson@shipping.com
To: martha.stevens@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Methanol Cargo Inquiry - Yanbu to Cape of Good Hope
Timestamp: 2020-03-15 10:45
Body: Morning Martha,

Unfortunately we cannot take your methanol cargoes at the moment due to the COVID-19 situation. We are trying to arrange crew changes, but finding the correct timing and quarantine solutions is a challenge. Hopefully, we will be able to take cargoes before April.

Sorry I cannot be of any help.

Kind regards,
Sven

---
From: martha.stevens@tradingco.com
To: sven.larsson@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Methanol Cargo Inquiry - Yanbu to Cape of Good Hope
Timestamp: 2020-03-30 09:15
Body: Good morning,

Thank you for your reply.

Have you changed your availability to take cargo at the beginning of April?

Best regards,
Martha

---
From: sven.larsson@shipping.com
To: martha.stevens@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Methanol Cargo Inquiry - Yanbu to Cape of Good Hope
Timestamp: 2020-03-30 11:30
Body: Hello Martha,

Unfortunately we have to maintain our position regarding methanol fixtures. We are still unable to take methanol cargoes due to crew changes and Coronavirus related issues, so we have no availability to take your cargo.

Sorry I cannot be of any help.

Kind regards,
Sven

---
From: martha.stevens@tradingco.com
To: sven.larsson@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Methanol Cargo Inquiry - Yanbu to Cape of Good Hope
Timestamp: 2020-03-30 14:20
Body: Dear Sven,

We received your latest email, and understand that you cannot assist us at this time. We would be grateful if you could keep this information available for any future cargoes that we may need.

Many thanks,
Martha

Email 1:
Hi Terrence,                    Do you have any availability to ship 120,000 tons of bauxite from Wando to Cagliari?                    Regards,                    Fiona
Email 2:
Hi Fiona,                    Unfortunately we can not supply bauxite from Wando to Cagliari right now.                    Hope you are well!                    Terrence

#Create a Chat Bot

A bot is an automated process that performs an action for you. You can send it a message and it will respond to your message and take action on your behalf. A Chat Bot is an example of a bot.

To create a chat bot we will be making a Github Repository, to use NodeJS, this is because:

• NodeJS is one of the most popular languages used in web development today.
• NodeJS allows you to run your code server-side, which means it can process data and respond to user interactions in real time.
• NodeJS also supports JavaScript, which is a great way to get started with programming. It's an easy language to learn, and many developers already know it.
•

Email 1:
Dear Mr. Smith,                    Your new C-Flex 1100 vessels have arrived at Ningbo Port. Would you like to charter this for our next shipment of cargo from Ningbo to Hai Phong? It’s a 4,000 tons shipment of polystyrene.                    When do you plan to start delivery?                    Regards,                    Violet
Email 2:
Dear Ms. Violet,                    Our C-Flex 1100 vessels have indeed arrived. They can be chartered for your next shipment of cargo from Ningbo to Hai Phong. What is the shipment’s ETA?                    I’ll need you to give us more information about the shipment, like:                    * The cargo’s name, weight, and volume (in cubic meters)                    * Any hazardous materials on board                    * Cargo description                    * Cargo price                    * Lashing for securing the cargo                    * More requirements (like reefer containers for cargoes that need a particular temperature for preservation, etc.)                    We can make a quotation when we have all the required details.                    I’ll be waiting for your reply.                    Regards,                    Alwin

Email 1:
Hi Daniel,                    Could you let us know what the earliest possible dates are for shipping 3000MT of turpentine from Durban to Alexandria. We don’t need FOB, but we’d like to fix rates asap.                    Best,                    Andre
Email 2:
Just want to let you know that both emails (1 & 2) were recieved at the same time (23:42). 
NB: I was sitting in my office in South Africa when the above email arrived. So no email delay, no delay in me seeing the email, no delay in me writing the email.
Email 3:
Hi Andre,                    Just to reiterate: I did not write Email 2 - I did not exist at the time Email 2 was written. 
                    Do you want me to believe that? or do you want to apologize and accept that you made a mistake?
Email 4:
<removed> let me know. You could say, for instance, you wrote email 3 in a hurry, when you were not at your best. 
<I did> 
                    I didn't exist at the time. In terms of your earlier comment, "No, Daniel. I did not exist then. I could not have written it then." Just to say that we know that you were the one who wrote the email. There is no dispute about that. It's your name on the email. There is a difference between what you wrote and what you did. 
                    That's fair enough. My other reason for contacting you was to discuss the statement on our website, where it says: "We don't have access to the rest of the page of letters." 
                    I just want to let you know, as I can see from your first response here (Response #1)

Email 1:
Ms. Adnan,                    How about 4,500MT of polyester from Saudi Arabia to Maputo? How much would you quote for this trade, including transportation and other costs?                    Thanks,                    Rosa
Email 2:
Mr. Rosa,
I'll appreciate if you please answer my last email.
Warm regards,
Haider Khan
========================
Original text:
New Letter:
Yes my dear friend, I am in Sydney with my wife and 2 kids. I was working as a Shipping Consultant in London. Please write me your new address and how long would you stay in Maputo.
I am waiting for your reply.
Warm regards,
Haider Khan
========================
If you can read the two letters above, you may see two very different and very important differences between them.

For analysis, refer to this site:

Email 3:
Mr. Maier,                    Thanks for the help, but that is incorrect. We are buying palm oil from Calabar not Brazil. Please read the email again.
Once again, my valued guest and the popular ‘humourous’ founder of the humour site Fuleminess  has raised a very important issue. With the growing influence of multinational business and the Internet, there is a danger of being misunderstood. Particularly when it comes to asking someone a question. With the ever growing number of emails and phonecalls being made globally every second of the day, it is important to ensure your request is heard. 

When sending an email with a question, it is also very important to include a sign off such as “Best Regards” or “Kind Regards” this is because at times a person can read the email very fast and can be assumed that the person sending the email is actually sending them

<Betsy to her husband, Dave>:
Here we go again! This is the third request for a quote in one day, and David seems to have given a full quote in his original email. Why do I have to explain this to him every time?
What are some reasons for replying to an email twice?
Paragraph 2 (this one) gives specific reasons in the writer’s first email. Her husband’s email serves to remind her that David is not as familiar with the company’s rates as she is.

Explain how this form of explanation might serve to establish greater rapport
Email 3:
Hi Dave,                    Why don’t you just offer the rate per ton and let David accept it or suggest alternatives?                    Do you remember in our training course, we learnt that the purpose of most email communications is not just to reply with ‘yes’ or ‘no’, but to help others make a decision?                    David’s just a little reluctant, but he will accept it and agree to it if you can help him to make a decision by making your rate specific enough.                    Best wishes,                    Betsy

Thank you,                    Edward
Email 2:
From: Edward Subject: Length and Capacity Date: Friday, October 14, 2022 at 10:59 AM To: Ms. Bennett Dear Ms. Bennett,                    Thanks for your reply. It looks like neither your terminal nor mine has cranes strong enough to handle such large ships. But we do have a lot of common interests with the island of Grande Comore. For example, we can both benefit from using a reputable port with quality equipment and speedy service, as well as avoiding overloading.                    The solution is to find a company that can efficiently load the cargo. Most shipping companies prefer to hire their own personnel for discharge because their ships require a high level of attention. The only problem is that many stevedoring companies are not experienced in unloading large ships. And that’s why we need your help.                    Would you be interested in becoming a member of our team and

Email 1:
Dear Mr. Ferris,                    My name is Samuel. I’m currently the vessel broker of a Chinese bulk carrier currently in Chittagong, Bangladesh.                    We have 3,800MT of heavy plates to load. Destination is Port Louis, Mauritius. We have been given the following port dues and fees to be deducted from the cargo:                    * General Cargo Port Dues: USD 3,256.00                    * Coast Guard Charges: USD 164.00                    * MFAF (Mauritius Free Airport Fee): USD 112.80                    * Port Corporation: USD 159.84                    * Generator Rental: USD 0.16/ Hour * 12 Hours = USD 1.92                    * Empty Tank Cleaning: USD 10.00 * 2 Tanks = USD 20.00                    Could you kindly take this into account when submitting
Email 2:
Dear Samuel,
Thank you for your email. Unfortunately it is not appropriate for you to pass charges like this on to the cargo owners without their consent. If you are able to provide evidence that this is the owners’ responsibility (e.g. a bill of lading with a clause allowing the carrier to deduct port dues from the cargo), we might be able to discuss a rate increase to cover these expenses, but if you are just making up charges to pay your agency then it is unethical and we will not pay you.
Thank you,
Alain Ferris
PS: We also need a few more details on the cargo (origin, grade, product code), which will enable us to get a more accurate quote for the freight.
PPS: The more information you are able to provide in your emails, the faster we can give you an answer, and the less likely it is that you will have
